repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
It isn't actually usable because it cimports other modules but it does build without warning. Changes are mainly to string handling (because that's the nature of parsing).

Depends on #5841 and #5798 to actually build Parsing.py, but the PR itself can be applied independently.

comment_data.body: This is unfortunate, because it may lead to an unused label. In rare cases, admittedlyâ€¦
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -14193,6 +14194,9 @@ def generate_result_code(self, code):
             checks = ["(%s != Py_None)" % self.arg.py_result()] if self.arg.may_be_none() else []
             checks.append("(%s(%s) != 0)" % (test_func, self.arg.py_result()))
             code.putln("%s = %s;" % (self.result(), '&&'.join(checks)))
+            code.putln("#if !CYTHON_ASSUME_SAFE_MACROS")
+            code.putln(code.error_goto_if_neg(self.result(), self.pos))

comment_data.body: It seems worth generally unfolding this lengthy macro into the inline function you wrote, and just special casing the size check.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -79,12 +87,17 @@ static int __Pyx_IternextUnpackEndCheck(PyObject *retval, Py_ssize_t expected) {
 
 /////////////// UnpackTuple2.proto ///////////////
 
+#if CYTHON_ASSUME_SAFE_MACROS
 #define __Pyx_unpack_tuple2(tuple, value1, value2, is_tuple, has_known_size, decref_tuple) \
     (likely(is_tuple || PyTuple_Check(tuple)) ? \
         (likely(has_known_size || PyTuple_GET_SIZE(tuple) == 2) ? \
             __Pyx_unpack_tuple2_exact(tuple, value1, value2, decref_tuple) : \
             (__Pyx_UnpackTupleError(tuple, 2), -1)) : \
         __Pyx_unpack_tuple2_generic(tuple, value1, value2, has_known_size, decref_tuple))
+#else
+static CYTHON_INLINE int __Pyx_unpack_tuple2(
+    PyObject* tuple, PyObject** value1, PyObject** value2, int is_tuple, int has_known_size, int decref_tuple);
+#endif

comment_data.body:
You could also pass `PY_SSIZE_T_MAX` as end to avoid the risk of an off-by-one error for `-1` (because, is that inclusive or exclusive?).

Given that there's a C-API function for this, though, I wonder if we're really still faster than that. The implementation seems quite efficient. From my expecience, `PyUnicode_READ()` isn't the fastest thing to use, compared to a straight memory loop.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -113,6 +113,14 @@ static int __Pyx_PyUnicodeBufferContainsUCS4_BMP(Py_UNICODE* buffer, Py_ssize_t
 #endif
 
 static CYTHON_INLINE int __Pyx_UnicodeContainsUCS4(PyObject* unicode, Py_UCS4 character) {
+#if CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_LIMITED_API
+    // Note that from Python 3.7, the indices of FindChar account for wraparound so no
+    // need to check the length
+    Py_ssize_t idx = PyUnicode_FindChar(unicode, character, 0, -1, 1);

@@ -113,6 +113,14 @@ static int __Pyx_PyUnicodeBufferContainsUCS4_BMP(Py_UNICODE* buffer, Py_ssize_t
 #endif
 
 static CYTHON_INLINE int __Pyx_UnicodeContainsUCS4(PyObject* unicode, Py_UCS4 character) {
+#if CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_LIMITED_API
+    // Note that from Python 3.7, the indices of FindChar account for wraparound so no
+    // need to check the length
+    Py_ssize_t idx = PyUnicode_FindChar(unicode, character, 0, -1, 1);
+    if (idx == -1) return 0;  // not found
+    else if (unlikely(idx < 0)) return -1; // error
+    else return 1; // found

comment_data.body:
I'm aware that this only changes something for the Limited API, but I doubt that it makes a difference here. If `PyUnicode_READ_CHAR()` really wanted to fail here, we'd already have gotten a failure for the `GetLength()` call above.
```suggestion
       return __Pyx_PyUnicode_READ_CHAR(x, 0);
```
(Apparently, this whole function is badly indented. Since you're changing most of it, it seems a good moment to switch it to 4 spaces.)

I can rewrite it as

```
if ((!CYTHON_ASSUME_SAFE_MACROS) && %result% < 0) goto error
```

so the label is never unused. That might be slightly better (provided we manage to avoid "condition always true" warnings)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -14193,6 +14194,9 @@ def generate_result_code(self, code):
             checks = ["(%s != Py_None)" % self.arg.py_result()] if self.arg.may_be_none() else []
             checks.append("(%s(%s) != 0)" % (test_func, self.arg.py_result()))
             code.putln("%s = %s;" % (self.result(), '&&'.join(checks)))
+            code.putln("#if !CYTHON_ASSUME_SAFE_MACROS")
+            code.putln(code.error_goto_if_neg(self.result(), self.pos))

comment_data.body: I've taken this to mean "just use PyUnicode_FindChar in all cases". Happy to revert if this wasn't what you mean though!
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -113,6 +113,14 @@ static int __Pyx_PyUnicodeBufferContainsUCS4_BMP(Py_UNICODE* buffer, Py_ssize_t
 #endif
 
 static CYTHON_INLINE int __Pyx_UnicodeContainsUCS4(PyObject* unicode, Py_UCS4 character) {
+#if CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_LIMITED_API
+    // Note that from Python 3.7, the indices of FindChar account for wraparound so no
+    // need to check the length
+    Py_ssize_t idx = PyUnicode_FindChar(unicode, character, 0, -1, 1);

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
#if !CYTHON_ASSUME_SAFE_SIZE        
```

```suggestion
#if !CYTHON_ASSUME_SAFE_SIZE
```

```suggestion
    #if CYTHON_ASSUME_SAFE_SIZE
```
This isn't quite right - the `__Pyx_PyUnicode_Substring` function handles negative indices and `PyUnicode_Substring` doesn't. Will fix
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -559,12 +497,18 @@ static CYTHON_INLINE PyObject* __Pyx_decode_bytearray(
 
 /////////////// PyUnicode_Substring.proto ///////////////
 
+#if !CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_LIMITED_API
 static CYTHON_INLINE PyObject* __Pyx_PyUnicode_Substring(
             PyObject* text, Py_ssize_t start, Py_ssize_t stop);
+#else
+// In the limited API since 3.7
+#define __Pyx_PyUnicode_Substring(text, start, stop) PyUnicode_Substring(text, start, stop)

comment_data.body: We haven't actually set `key` in this case either. We need to decref both (and `value` in the failure case below).

We must call this either way.
```suggestion
    if (unlikely(__Pyx_PyUnicode_READY(text) == -1)) return NULL;
```

We can't - it isn't in the limited API, and the call is already in `PyUnicode_GetLength()` (https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/0f56adb8d74e703974811620559d96c999334547/Objects/unicodeobject.c#L4016) in versions old enough that it matters.

`PyTuple_SetItem` decrefs `key` on failure (https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/939fc6d6eab9b7ea8c244d513610dbdd556503a7/Objects/tupleobject.c#L122C10-L122C10) so that it effectively steals a reference whether or not it succeeds.

I'll add a comment because it isn't obvious though
Ah, right. I had looked only in CPython master and it didn't have it any more because it's no longer available in Py3.13. It is there in older versions that need it, yes.

commit.message:
Build Parsing.py in the limited api

It isn't actually usable because it cimports other modules
but it does build without warning. Changes are mainly to string
handling (because that's the nature of parsing).

Depends on #5841 and #5798 to actually build, but the PR itself
doesn't depend on those

Apply suggestions from code review

Co-authored-by: scoder <stefan_ml@behnel.de>
